metadata.case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Ridmal Singh & Balji

facts.text: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar was elected to the House of the People from Jhunjhunu Parliamentary Constituency in Rajasthan at the third general elections held in February 1962.
Election Petition No. 269 of 1962 filed by Ridmal Singh, an elector in the constituency, to set aside the appellant's election.
Election Petition No. 295 of 1962 filed by Balji, an elector whose nomination paper was rejected by the returning officer.
Appellant filed preliminary objections on July 6, 1962, to the maintainability of the two election petitions.
Election Tribunal dismissed preliminary objections by orders dated August 13, 1962, and passed consequential orders on August 14, 1962.
Appellant filed writ petitions in Rajasthan High Court praying to quash Tribunal orders and dismiss election petitions for non-compliance with Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Rajasthan High Court dismissed writ petitions by order dated August 31, 1962.
Supreme Court granted special leave; appeals preferred.
Ballu or Balji's nomination paper was rejected; not a contesting candidate.
Copy of Election Petition No. 269 served on appellant lacked petitioner's signature at foot and omitted para 14-g(ii) in verification.
Affidavit accompanying Election Petition No. 269 on corrupt practices had defect due to inexperience of Oaths Commissioner: 'verified by me' instead of 'verified before me'.

Copy of Election Petition No. 295 served on appellant lacked reproduction of four enclosures (treasury receipt, certified copy of rejection order dated 22-1-1962, etc.), no date/place in verification.
Dr. Z. A. Ahmed intervened in appeals on April 4, 1963.

legal_issues.text: Whether Election Petition No. 269/1962 non-compliant with s.82 due to improper joinder of Ballu/Balji as respondent No.7, who was not a contesting candidate.
Whether copy of Election Petition No. 269 served on appellant was a true copy under s.81(3) due to missing signature and verification omission.
Whether affidavit on corrupt practices in Election Petition No. 269 was properly made/in prescribed form under proviso to s.83(1).
Whether Election Petition No. 295 non-compliant with s.81(3) due to missing enclosures in served copy, lack of verification date/place, etc.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.82 mandatory; improper joinder of non-contesting candidate Ballu/Balji fatal, requires dismissal under s.90(3).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 ss.82, 90(3)

petitioner_arguments.text: Copy served not true copy under s.81(3): no signature at foot, omitted para 14-g(ii) in verification; mandatory, attracts s.90(3).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 ss.81(3), 90(3); Sri Babu Ran v. Shrimati Prasanni

petitioner_arguments.text: Affidavit not in prescribed form/properly sworn; non-compliance with s.83 proviso fatal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.83(1) proviso; Conduct of Election Rules, 1961

petitioner_arguments.text: Election Petition 295 copy not true: enclosures not reproduced, no verification date/place, missing treasury receipt copy and signed rejection order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.81(3)

respondent_arguments.text: Joinder of extra party not breach of s.82 if all necessary parties joined; can strike out unnecessary party.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.82

respondent_arguments.text: 'Copy' means substantially true, not exact transcript; defects not misleading.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.81(3); Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar

respondent_arguments.text: Verification defects curable under CPC principles; s.90(3) does not cover s.83 non-compliance.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.83(1)(c), s.90; Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

court_reasoning.text: s.82 requires joining all contesting candidates; excess joinder of non-necessary party like Ballu (non-contesting) not contravention; all necessary joined. Tribunal can strike out.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.82 does not say 'and no others'; no warrant to add words.

court_reasoning.text: Verification defects in petitions not fatal; within s.83(1)(c), curable per CPC; s.90(3) excludes s.83.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defect in stating belief in advice true not attracting dismissal.

court_reasoning.text: Copy under s.81(3) attested per page by petitioner; no need fresh signature at foot. Omission in verification para not misleading.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Copy' means so true no one can misunderstand; not exact transcript.

court_reasoning.text: Affidavit defect due to Oaths Commissioner inexperience ('verified by me' vs 'before me'); reading whole, conveys same sense; not fatal, can file later.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.83 not necessary for validity under s.81.

court_reasoning.text: Petition 295 defects: verification date/place curable; enclosures mentioned in body or verified; no need vakalatnama copy or repeat endorsement; not misleading.

holdings.text: Joinder of unnecessary party not non-compliance with s.82 if all required parties joined.
'Copy' under s.81(3) means true copy not calculated to mislead ordinary person; substantial compliance.
Verification defects under s.83(1)(c) curable per CPC; affidavit defect not fatal.
Defects in Petition 295 copies/enclosures/verification not invalidating under s.81(3).

precedents_cited.relevance: s.82 then not mandatory; noted law changed but not determinative as no s.82 breach.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Babu Ran v. Shrimati Prasanni
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict compliance where statute specifies consequence; applied to argue s.81(3) mandatory but court found compliance.
Omission of words in copy not invalid if no alteration in meaning.
Minor omission in copy immaterial if not misleading.
Description in writ sufficient without full addition.
Omission of addition in copy may invalidate.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Hewer Ex parte Kahen
precedents_cited.relevance: True copy under Bills of Sale Act: clerical errors ok if not misleading.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs presentation, parties, contents, copies, affidavits, dismissal for non-compliance in election petitions.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Applicable to trial per s.90(1); for curing verification defects under s.83(1)(c).

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed both appeals, finding no merit in preliminary objections to maintainability of election petitions; all defects in copies, joinder, verification, affidavit held non-fatal with substantial compliance.

key_quotes.text: "if all the necessary parties have been joined to the election petition, the circumstance that a person who is not a necessary party has also been impleaded does not amount to a breach of the provisions of s. 82"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the word 'copy' in sub-s. (3) of s. 81 does not mean an absolutely exact copy, but means that the copy shall be so true that nobody can by any possibility misunderstand it"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The mistake of the Oaths Commissioner in verifying the affidavit cannot be a sufficient ground for dismissal of the petitioners petition summarily"
key_quotes.speaker: court
